results.description:
“Creating the Smart City with LED Street Lighting”
Talk by STEPHEN QUICK, FAIA LEED-AP SEED
Principal, Civic Design and Planning LLC
Adjunct Professor of Architecture/Urban Design, Carnegie Mellon

Stephen Quick is a practicing urban designer and planner, architect, and educator.

Steve is an Adjunct Professor of Architecture at Carnegie Mellon teaching in both the graduate and undergraduate programs with a concentration on urban design, systems integration, performance-based design, and civic engagement. He is a Research Associate with the Remaking Cities Institute in the School of Architecture and currently manages the LED Street Light Research Project for the City of Pittsburgh, involving specification recommendations for retrofitting the City’s street lights with energy-saving LEDs and “smart” controls, and the Highway Corridor Transformation Research Study, creating new planning guidelines for a more holistic and community-focused process and approach to transportation corridor planning for PennDOT and the Federal Highway Administration.

Civic Design and Planning LLC, Steve’s private practice, is a strategic and advisory consulting firm focusing on urban issues and the physical environment. Steve has been active in community leadership in Pittsburgh and service to the architectural profession on a national, state and local basis. His work has received awards in urban and regional design, architecture, and green building design.
results.name: FREE TALK: Creating the Smart City with LED Street Lighting

results.description:
The Pittsburgh Change Ringing Guild meets regularly on Thursday nights to practice and hone our change ringing skills.

Non-ringers are welcome to attend Thursday night practices to come check out what we do.  When entering the tower, the most important rule is DO NOT touch the ropes unless specifically instructed to by an experienced bell ringer.  If people are currently ringing the bells when you walk in the room, please come in quietly and have a seat around the edges of the room.  We will stop ringing in a few minutes, and can give you an introduction to the bells.

Non-Ringers can also have an opportunity to try pulling the bell under the guidance of an experienced bell ringer.  We are also more than happy to teach you the ancient art of bell ringing.
Learning to ring the bells does take some time before you would be able to ring comfortably on your own.  Obviously the more effort you put into it the more quickly you would be able to ring confidently on your own.  You can expect 4-6 weeks of individual instruction to get to that stage.  And then once you learn how to handle the bells, that opens up a lifetime of ringing opportunities!

Check out the videos below to see what the bell ringing is like, and you are more than welcome to come join us for our practice night!  Please RSVP if you are coming, because practices sometimes get cancelled for various reasons.

Bells swinging: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=liuRptmR088 
Ringers pulling ropes: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M1vSfNF7OfI
results.how_to_find_us: Enter Southminster church by the doors between the church and the middle school. Either walk to the 4th floor or take the elevator to the 4th floor. Turn left and continue up the stairs to the Bell Tower.
results.name: Change Ringing Practice Night

results.description:
As an Entrepreneur, you have a unique mix of joys and challenges. No one can really prepare you for what it's like to be your own boss and manage so many different aspects of finance, technology, time management, continuing education, long-term planning, marketing, customer service...to name a few!

Having our own business has been our life's dream, but sometimes the stress can be overwhelming. We have to be extra aware of taking care of ourselves mentally, emotionally and physically. 

For March's Meetup, Psychologist and Mastermind member Dr. Elaine Malec will be sharing "How Mindset Affects Wellness". From her years of experience as a psychologist and now her new experiences as an Entrepreneur, she will teach us stress management techniques and how to maintain emotional and mental wellness. 

Just a reminder that this group is different from other women's groups that are primarily geared towards networking. We exchange business cards in order to keep in touch, but this is not a venue for recruiting customers or clients. Thank you for respecting the purpose of this specific group.
results.name: Taking care of You. Avoiding Burnout and Managing Stress as an Entrepreneur.

results.description: The "Incito Veritas" founding fathers (which included females, of course, as no soul has a gender) originally called this group "Fight Club" and first intended to keep that name while maintaining secrecy. So much for that. But the spirit of Fight Club remains, the idea of trying to bring out the best in each other through the evolution of consciousness. As Brad Pitt said about the movie, "Fight Club is a metaphor for the need to push through the walls we put around ourselves and just go for it." And not fear the pain! In this meetup we discuss ways that concepts introduced during the Incito Veritas series can be applied to our daily lives. We will learn and grow as we process our experiences. Bottom line: Knowing and Not Doing is Not Knowing, or as it says in James 2:26, "For as the body without the spirit is dead, so faith without works is dead."
results.name: Fight Club: Ready ... Set ... Action!

results.description:
A seminar presented by Amy Lohr, where the concept of Sacred Pain will be defined and explored. The paired words "Sacred Pain" often provoke immediate reactions from curiosity to resistance to disdain, fear or relief. 


A phrase coined by Amy to describe the commonality of the human experience: the culmination of pain and struggles that all of us experience on our life journey. Sacred Pain is also the pain that we automatically brace against, resist, or tense to on a physical, emotional, mental, or spiritual level.  This "tensing to" and "resisting" pain in our life is what creates suffering, not the actual pain itself. It is counter-intuitive to embrace and accept our pain, so it is not our "go to" response to do so.  It takes training and guidance to accept our pain and revere it in a way that allows us to accept the gifts of Sacred Pain.  Our pain is worthy of being revered, honored, and held with care, and compassion. Sacred Pain affords us the gifts of peace, healing, love, compassion, and wisdom. You may have great resistance to these truths, which is a normal initial response. Amy will describe how pain can afford these opportunities. Ultimately, it is through our deepest, darkest, scariest experiences that we have the opportunity to the most significant growth in our life journey. 

This seminar will further discuss these concepts, as Amy demonstrates creating a vessel for her Sacred Pain - an experience you won't want to miss! Through sharing her story of adversity and resiliency, in passion and strength, you will observe the embodiment of Radical Acceptance with pain (practice of mindfulness & compassion). A seminar that will empower and inspire you to practice the same skills with your Sacred Pain.

~~~~~~

Stay tuned for additional seminars related to the concept of Sacred Pain, Mindfulness, Wellness, Spirituality & More! As we continue to explore new opportunities and methods to address the need for Mindfulness through practice, education, and embodiment.
results.name: Seminar: "Creating A Vessel For Sacred Pain"

results.description:
Get Heard! Get Noticed! Get Leads! (TM)

Hosted by: Edie Coates from Ace In The Hole Entertainment and MaryBeth Kratsus of MBK Photography

This is an informal networking event, open to any business woman who would like to increase her business contacts or clients in the Monroeville area.

Things to bring:

- 10-20 business cards or marketing material

- cash for your lunch check

- $5 meeting fee (non members only)


AGENDA

1:00 pm - attendees arrive, reviews menu, gives the server their drink order, and open networking: everyone stands up to introduce oneself to others and pass their business card

1:15 pm - server takes lunch order and the sign in sheet is passed around

1:30 pm - 60 sec. commercials begin

2:00 pm - each person gives a testimony or referral for someone attending the lunch

2:15 pm - Premier member does a 5 min. company presentation

2:20 pm - WSBA announcements from Debi/Susan

2:30 pm - lunch has ended. Open networking is welcomed.

Be prepared to do a 60 second commercial about yourself. Please RSVP if you plan to attend this lunch. If your schedule becomes free the day of the lunch, then you may attend without an RSVP. This lunch is subject to cancellation when the lunch has 3 or less RSVPs.Lunch cancellation policy.

If you are not a WSBA member and would like to attend as a guest, please email Debi Arnett @ [masked]


If you have an interest in becoming a General member ($50/year) or Premier member ($100/year) of WSBA, please contact <a>Debi Arnett </a>or [masked]

Any non member will be removed from this site, if they RSVP and they do not attend.

results.description:
10TH ANNUAL LOCAL FOOD CONFERENCE

March 18 & 19, 2016


I plan to attend on Friday with my family and we usually pack a lunch/snacks.  We would love to meet more of the DIY Natural Health Meetup group members, so let's meet at 1:30pm outside the conference/vendor hall in the common/open space area where they set up tables.


We will be wearing Meetup name badges and I will bring a sign as well.  Please do say hello, introduce yourself and even sit down and grab a snack with us.  Don't feel obligated to walk around with me ;)  Posting this Meetup to encourage more of us to GET OUT and meet one another!

Learn more - check out Farm to Table site and the speaker lineup:
http://farmtotablepa.com/conference/speakers


Farm to Table means many things: Knowing where your food comes from; accessing fresh nutritional food; supporting local businesses; and last but not least, getting back to our roots.


The conference provides consumers with two days of networking and educational opportunities. Seasonal cooking demonstrations, gardening, and information about the nutritional value of local food are presented by local experts.

Meet with other Locavores to discuss ideas about where their food comes from and where to find businesses and organizations who can provide them with healthy food and healthy lifestyle choices.

results.description:
Hello everyone!

It is great to be back in Pittsburgh playing some games!  We had ten gamers show up at the last meetup and we got a lot of great games on the table.  We primarily had three tables going with 3-4 players at each.  

So of the games played were Bruges, Russian Railroads, Keltis, Lanterns, Hanabi, The Voyages of Marco Polo, and Diamonds.

This week's theme goes out to our regular co-organizer Andrew a.k.a. (Redbeard) and it is Ameritrash Games!

So the Wiki definition of an Ameritrash game is a genre of board games predominant in the United States, characterized by a high degree of luck, longer playtimes, player conflict, and highly-developed, often dramatic themes, especially involving war or adventure.  

So I am going to take it upon my self this week to learn one of my games called Bootleggers and bring and teach it.  

Anyone else who has an Ameritrash game they would like to bring to game night and be willing to instruct and run please list it in the chat.  If there is a game you see featured and you would like to play it please say so in the chat window and we will do our best to hold a seat for you.

Looking forward to Friday night, hope to see you there.

Today's board games come in all different shapes, sizes, themes, components, and our group plays all kinds.. Here are some examples of the types of games we play...

Party games like:  Codenames, Spyfall, and Dixit.

Euro style games like:  Five Tribes, Orleans, Puerto Rico, Viticulture, and Lords of Waterdeep. 

Abstract games like:  Qwirkle, Blokus, and Hive

Card games like:  Dominion, Glory to Rome, Diamonds, and Munchkin

Those are just a few of the games that can be seen being played at our meetups every week.

Our members come in all shapes and sizes and span from young to older but all seem to have a great time when we get together!

Our organizers try to be very accommodating to new players and try to pick games appropriate to your skill level and that we think you would enjoy.  Our goal is to get you enthusiastic about the hobby.

If there is a game that you would like to try out just r.s.v.p. to one of our meetups and suggest it down in the chat.  Chances are that one of us has it in our collection and we can bring it out.

Look forward to introducing the hobby to many more players in 2016 and continued good times with our regulars.

Please r.s.v.p. early so I have an idea on how many people or coming and what games to bring along.  You can always cancel your r.s.v.p. if you have a change of plans.


See you soon!

Russ.

Important INFO:If someone in the group picks a place early in the Arts Crawl to meet in the Comments, I will make you the organizer of the Event and this will make this a better time and you get to MEET people and have MORE FUN! (Frank the Admin), this is currently an UN-HOSTED EVENT, but a GREAT ONE!

Special Pittsburgh Bicentennial Gallery Crawl

200 year ago, on March 18, 1816, Pittsburgh officially became a city when the legislature of the Commonwealth of PA voted to approve Pittsburgh's incorporation.

The Bicentennial Commission and Partners, composed of more than 300 organizations—including businesses, arts and cultural organizations, higher education, and neighborhood collaboratives—is hosting an Inaugural Celebration on March 18, 2016. Pittsburgh's Incorporation Charter will be in Pittsburgh and on exhibit for the first time in 200 years!
Everyone's invited to enjoy music provided by local choirs; pop up displays of historical artifacts (including Pittsburgh's Charter on view at the City-County Building); updates on the search for our missing time capsule!

For more information, visit: TrustArts.org/crawl

For listing of events, visit: http://crawl.trustarts.org/event/
results.how_to_find_us: Check out the multiple locations / events on the links below
results.name: Wonderful EVENT: Pittsburgh Bicentennial Gallery Crawl (Arts Crawl)

results.description:
The notion of a salutation to the sun is to pay your respects and surrender to the universe.  This is a metaphor to let go physically.  The mind follows the actions of the body; in short, it is a moving meditation.

Join Jen Stratakis, E-RYT for this beautiful practice; the tradition of 108 Sun Salutations is healing and energizing. The flow of poses will be accompanied by the traditional mantras for this classical series. Participants do NOT need to complete every sun salutation; but that challenge is there,  if you want it!

Pausing to rest is acceptable and encouraged. Simply stay in the spirit of the practice, with the option of resting in Mountain Pose or Child’s Pose.

We will end our practice with a purge pot ceremony to symbolize letting go of what you don't need, in this season of renewal.

http://www.uecpgh.com/
results.name: Practice 108 Sun Salutes to Welcome Spring

results.description:
Finding Insurance companies that will cover Medical Cannabis businesses is a critical issue. Surety Bond specialist Karen Canton has more than 30 years experience in the industry, and from her Las Vegas office, is doing business in a growing number of Medical Cannabis businesses in legal states, including Pennsylvania (when approved). 


In this MicroWebinar, she will outline the necessities and the common pitfalls, and offer the most current analysis of any pending or current legislation.


This 30-minute MicroWebinar, with half the time allotted for questions from participants is part of a Special Preview of PAMCS Webinars and will be free for PAMCS Members and also Free to the Public.

--

The previous MicroWebinar can be seen below:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wZK9mW78Uj4
results.name: PAMCS MicroWebinar - Insurance Prejudice

Sorry for rescheduling.... something came up that night and I will need to reschedule 

LETS TRY SOMETHING DIFFERENT AND TRY THE LOCAL BREWERY CHURCH BREW WORKS. KNOWN FOR GREAT FOOD AND HIGH QUALITY BEER SELECTION.

Celestial Gold ABV: 4.0%
Golden in color with a light, bubbly effervescence. From the start, you will notice a fine hop aroma and a light malt taste. Pipe Organ Pale Ale ABV: 5.2%
Brewed with a hefty amount of pale malt and loads of Galaxy Hops, this beer is a medium bodied ale with a light malt sweetness from the use of caramel malts. Balanced and sure to please, the Pipe Organ Pale Ale finishes crisp and citrusy with hints of peach and passionfruit.

Pious Monk Dunkel ABV: 5.5%
The body is mellow and the alcohol content is low. It has a wonderful clean and roasty aroma and finishes crisp and clean as a lager should.

Rotating Stout
Today there are many different variations of stout available all over the world. To celebrate this diversity, we constantly rotate our stout selection. We might be brewing an old favorite or experimenting with a new batch, so ask your server what's on tap.

ThunderHop IPA ABV – 6.5%
Intense bitterness, flavor and aroma. Hopped with an equal blend of Chinook and Nugget hops resulting an herbal, pine, citrus and grapefruit aroma and flavor. The color is copper to amber, just a bit darker than the Pipe Organ Pale Ale. The body is big and malty with some caramel sweetness.

Short-Day Dunkelweizen ABV - 5.5%
Dark amber brown with a bit of a haze due to the yeast. The aroma is very complex. It has some of the banana/clove-like aromas that original Hefeweizen has, but it also has a mixture of bread-like and chocolate-like overtones. The body is light to medium with a slight amount of residual sweetness. It will finish with the soft flavor of a wheat beer and no lingering hop bitterness.

Rufus Dark Saison ABV - 6.6%
Dark brown with a beige head. Notes of hazelnuts, chocolate, and wood blend well with the light peppery zing from the Wallonian yeast and white peppercorn addition. We also made this with bitter orange peel and coriander to balance out the darker flavors. Dark saisons are a newer sub-style of the traditional farmhouse ale, and to play with it even more, we made ours with rye instead of wheat.

Renegade Black IPA ABV – 6.0%
This beer isn’t quite a stout but it’s too dark to be an IPA. It might start out tasting kinda like a dry stout, but then the grassy and citrusy Amarillo hops kick in. We used Amarillos for bittering and the flavor/aroma additions. Judging that to be insufficient, we then dry-hopped the beer with Amarillos. We like the way Amarillos taste in this beer, so we went for it. Cherry Quadzilla ABV: 10.3%
The color is amber with some red hues and it also holds a nice rich head. The aroma will be distinctively Belgian in character. You will notice lots of fruit like esters and some roasted malt undertones. The body is full with bread-like maltiness and a bit of a lingering caramel sweetness. As the beer finishes you will get a slight balancing bitterness and then an alcohol warming effect. One interesting note: notice how the complexity of the Cherry Quad increases as the beer warms in your glass.

Spring Hill Sour ABV: 5.4%
Pale, tart, and refreshing -- it’s Berliner Weisse! We used apples in both the mash and fermenter using only hand-picked apples.

Mad Mardigan’s Spiced Baltic Porter ABV: 7.5%
A light mocha head and a dark brown color. The black cardamom we spiced it with gives it an apparent smokey, resinous aroma -- perfect for winter. The flavor has some slight sweetness (apt for the style) to balance out the spices and hint of Black malt.

Cask Ale Selection
Our brewers offer a rotating real ale naturally carbonated in the firkin, sometimes adding interesting ingredients or additional hops, and served on a traditional hand pump in a 20oz Imperial Pint. The beer will change every week, so be sure to ask what's on today!

Some history:
History of St. John's the Baptist and Lawrenceville
In the days before industry invaded its boundaries or paved roads curled through its neighborhoods, when Pittsburgh was in its youth, there was a farm called "Good Liquor" outside of the city. Owned by Alexander Hill, part of the farm was located within the existing Lawrenceville border. Later on, in 1814, William B. Foster purchased a 133-acre tract of land outside of Pittsburgh along the Allegheny River. In that same year, he would sell 30 acres of that property to the Federal Government. While Allegheny Arsenal was being built to provide supplies to the warring Union Troops during the civil war, Foster was starting to establish a community called Lawrenceville. The picturesque area was named for Captain James Lawrence who gained fame in the war with Britain. He was captain of the Chesapeake and his famous saying "Don't give up the ship!" was incorporated in the borough seal of Lawrenceville.
results.name: CHURCH BREW WORKS

FINE ART GALLERY EXHIBITION 

                    PRESENTED by "ARTISTS' GALLERY" 

                        FEATURING THE ARTWORK OF 
                    ARNE HANSEN AND GORDON SATRI 

                                  Exhibit Receptions 
  Friday & Saturday – March[masked]:30 PM – 8:30 PM
  Get your creative juices flowing by celebrating the 2016 Artists’ Gallery’s “Art Gallery Weekend Event Series” of monthly exhibitions. Each monthly event in the 2016 series will feature works by many of our established and burgeoning visual artists, performances by professional musicians and student musicians from local colleges, we will feature a variety of published and unpublished poetry and novelistic readings by some of our local authors, plus beautiful performances by local performing artists. These events will be held on the last Friday and Saturday evenings of each month beginning in March. We hope you will take the time to explore the dozens of artists on display and enjoy a weekend high-lighted by a celebration of the arts in Bellevue. 

Friday, March 18 at 6:30 PM will launch this exciting new series with the artwork styles of Arne Hansen and Gordon Satri. Tristan Reid will read from a selection of his writings on Friday evening and Saturday, March 19, will feature poet Nick Romeo. We are pleased to present the jazz sounds of the “Dante Romito Band" on Friday and Saturday evening. The band will be performing their first instrumental rock single, the “Guardian Angel”.
results.name: ART GALLERY WEEKEND EVENT SERIES - Bellevue

results.description:
FINE ART GALLERY EXHIBITION  

                    PRESENTED by "ARTISTS' GALLERY"

                       FEATURING THE ARTWORK OF
                  ARNE HANSEN AND GORDON SATRI

Exhibit Receptions – FREE
Friday & Saturday – March[masked] from 6:30 PM – 8:30 PM


Get your creative juices flowing by celebrating the 2016 Artists’ Gallery’s “Art Gallery Weekend Event Series” of monthly exhibitions.


Each monthly event in the 2016 series will feature works by many of our established and burgeoning visual artists, performances by professional musicians and student musicians from local colleges, we will feature a variety of published and unpublished poetry and novelistic readings by some of our local authors, plus beautiful performances by local performing artists.

These events will be held on the last Friday and Saturday evenings of each month beginning in March.


We hope you will take the time to explore the dozens of artists on display and enjoy a weekend high-lighted by a celebration of the arts in Bellevue.


Friday, March 18 at 6:30 PM will launch this exciting new series with the artwork styles of Arne Hansen and Gordon Satri. In addition, Tristan Reid will read from a selection of his writings on Friday evening and Saturday, March 19, will feature poet Nick Romeo.


We are pleased to present the jazz sounds of the Dante Romito Band on Friday and Saturday evening. The band will be performing their first instrumental rock single, the “Guardian Angel.” For more information about the Dante Romito Band (including song samples, etc.), please visit http://www.danteromitomusic.com/

Meetup Considerations

When you RSVP, please indicate whether you're interested in attending on Friday March 18 or Saturday March 19. On both Friday & Saturday nights, the exhibit reception will be from 6:30 PM – 8:30 PM.

As always, it is also OK if you prefer attending on your own with family and friends instead.

results.description: Join Sunday Assembly and the Steel City Skeptics for good beer and good conversation. Drinking Skeptically is an informal social event designed to promote fellowship and networking among skeptics, atheists, humanists, critical-thinkers, and like-minded individuals. There is no specific topic. It is just an open discussion among fellow freethinkers about science, religion, skepticism, beer, dinner, life and leisure. Both teetotalers and those who imbibe moderately are equally welcomed. We generally meet the third or fourth Friday of each month, skipping August and December. We start gathering at 7 pm, but latecomers are more than welcome. Hope to see you on Friday night!
results.name: Drinking With The Skeptics

results.description:
You're Invited!

• Join us for our March meet-up and meet other LGBT singles who are looking to make new friends, relationships, and expand their social circle, just like you. This month we will be at Sing Sing dueling piano bar in the Waterfront (beside Rock Bottom Brewery). This is a great way to meet in a very relaxed & friendly atmosphere.  We generally have between 40-50 people at most of our events, so it's always the perfect sized group for a nice party/get2gether.  

This month's event includes dinner & entertainment.  Total cost is $30 cash and includes fajita bar (with beef, chicken, black beans, and lots of veggies) chips & salsa, carrot cake, unlimited soft drinks, coffee, tea, and tax & tip. The entertainment will start after we all eat & socialize.  They'll be taking requests and do parodies of various popular songs and encourage guests to sing-a-long. It's gonna be a great time & a great way to meet lots of nice, new people in the local gay community.  Just click "join" on this months event if you can make it.  Hope to see you there.  It's going to be another great party!
results.name: Single Out social group for LGBT singles/March 2016 event

results.description:
Join us in celebrating the Spring Equinox through movement, music, and community at First United Methodist Church in Shadyside from 7-9pm THIS Friday, March 18th!

Ecstatic Dance – Seeds of Renewal is an all ages* evening of free-form dance and movement in a judgment-free zone :) No dance experience needed ~ No steps to learn! Come as you are, and move as you wish!

$10 at the door or pre-register via Eventbrite. Kids 16 & under are FREE! Pay what you Can option available ~ We value your presence far more than your money!

Our Ecstatic Dance journey will begin with warming up the body, mind, and spirit with a ritual for planting the seeds of renewal in our lives. We will then enjoy 1+ hours of dancing to the beat of our own drummers, accompanied by a totally awesome playlist inviting us to accept, unleash, and celebrate our individual and collective intentions of Renewal! Opening & Closing circles to connect and integrate.

Dancing is in bare feet or socks. Dress comfortably, preferably in layers, and bring water! ~ We look forward to moving with you!

Bring your hoops, dancing props, funky outfits, glowing decorations, your yoga moves, your salsa grooves, whatever it is that makes you move!

This event is hosted by Ecstatic Dance Pittsburgh. Visit us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/ecstaticdancepittsburgh/

*Children 16 and under must be accompanied by an adult 18 years or older.
results.name: Ecstatic Dance - Seeds of Renewal!

results.description:
The CMU International Film Festival welcomes Brenda Myers-Powell, the deeply inspiring woman behind the Dreamcatcher Foundation. If you don't think human trafficking is an American issue, Brenda will make you think otherwise!


JOIN US!  
Following the screening will be a Q&A with Brenda, Stephanie Daniels-Wilson, Co-Founder and CEO of the Dreamcatcher Foundation, and Jess Klein of CMU’s Survivor Support Network.  Continue the discussion at a dessert reception courtesy of The Butterwood Bake Consortium!

Sponsored by Sembéne: The Film & Arts Festival and supported by CMU’s Survivor Support Network and The Got Consent? Campaign.

EVENT INFO HERE | BUY TICKETS HERE

Find FREE parking at the Forbes Avenue Parking Lot after 5pm!


FILM DESCRIPTION  
“Dreamcatcher is a raw, powerful, and downright inspirational documentary that once again proves how much positive change even a single person can bring to the world.” –Oktay Ege Kozak, Indie Wire

Dreamcatcher explores the cycle of neglect, violence and exploitation which each year leaves thousands upon thousands of girls and women feeling that prostitution is the only means to survival. By following the very charming, charismatic and truly empathic Brenda  Myers-Powell, we enter the lives of young women and see in verité footage their realities from their points of view. While the world may overlook these women and men, thankfully Brenda has not, providing an unflinching expose which contrasts seeming hopelessness against the difference that one person can make in the lives of many.


TRAILER

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PMPXhevhw0U

Reception & Film Location

This event is General Admission (open seating) and takes place inside the Jared L. Cohen University Center (where the café areas are also located) next to the tennis courts.   And if you were standing on Forbes facing the main campus (near the bus shelter at Forbes & Morewood), you would see the famous 'Walking to the Sky' sculpture (where people appear to walking up a 10-story angled pole) in front of you, and the Cohen University Center would be very long building to your left. The McConomy Auditorium is on the 1st floor of the Cohen University Center. Please print out this campus map before you go http://www.cmu.edu/homeimages/campus-map/cmu_mapcolor_8x11.pdf -- the Cohen University Center is Building #13 on this map. 


Here is what the McConomy Auditorium looks like inside http://www.cmu.edu/cohon-university-center/reserve-space/event-spaces/mcconomy.html

CMU International Film Festival For the complete festival schedule and more info, including trailers of all of the films during CMU International Film Festival’s TENTH ANNIVERSARY season (March 17 - April 3, 2016), please visit http://www.cmu.edu/faces/index.html
results.name: ‘Dreamcatcher’ (USA, 2015) + Special Guest, Q&A, Reception!

results.description:
If you're into music, and even if you're not, here's a great opportunity to share any music you're interested in, have a cup of coffee or tea, and engage in conversation. We'll meet at Coffee Tree Roasters in Shadyside to chat, drink coffee, and listen to music. Bring your favorite music on your phone or thumb drive to share -- you can even bring an instrument to play if you'd like. And you can just come for the coffee and company – you absolutely aren't required to bring music (I will bring my laptop to look things up on YouTube as well).

Bring any music -- if you have music of your own creation, if you're passionate about a particular musician or band, or if you just like something and feel like sharing. It could be a recent find or something that influenced your childhood and got you though your teenage years. It could be something you love or it could even be something you hate -- just tell us why. Music is as much a story as anything -- it could be a story of you, or the story of the artist who created the music, or the story could be embedded in the song itself waiting for us to listen. Feel free to bring a story to share along with the music -- or not, if you prefer.

We're totally open to any kind of music so, please, bring anything you'd like to share be it classical, ethnic, heavy metal, or whatever -- even classical ethnic heavy metal (I bet it exists). We'll be meeting at Coffee Tree Roasters from 7pm (to probably 9pm though the room's booked until 10pm).

This event is also posted on meetin.org.
results.how_to_find_us: Inside Coffee Tree at 7pm, head to the glass-walled meeting room in the back.
results.name: Coffee Loves Music

results.description:
Join us at Swisshelm most Friday nights for contra dances. This is a recurring meetup, and we will try to cancel if there is a week without a dance, but double check the schedule at www.pittsburghcontra.org which is always up-to-date.

Dances are Fridays at Swisshelm Community Center, 8pm-11pm with a beginner's lesson at 7:30.

$7 for students, $10 for the rest of us folks.

Contra dancing is hungry business, if you'd like to bring a snack to share at the break, please do!

No experience necessary, no partner necessary, just bring your feet and a smile.

results.description:
Hey Friends,

Join us on Saturday March 19th for something really cool :-)

You're invited to the 1st Annual Pitt Mindfulness Fair to join, meet, connect, and experience mindful practices and practitioners from all walks of life. This event is being hosted by the newly opened University of Pittsburgh's Center for Mindfulness and Consciousness Studies(CMCS). The Mindfulness Fair will showcase 24 workshops on a range of awesome topics: Mindful Eating, Education, Therapy, Yoga, Tai Chi, etc...

Snacks will be provided, and best of all......there is NO charge for this event. ---> It's Free! (Kids Activities Too!)

Click below for the facebook event Page and details

https://www.facebook.com/events/171483423209825/

What is CMCS? CMCS is an interdisciplinary collaborative research center started by many different departments at the University of Pittsburgh to build and serve the Mindfulness Community, to Raise Awareness for the application of Mindfulness in all areas of our lives, and to conduct research on the positive effects of Mindfulness within Education, Mental Health, Public Health, and many other fields.


Over the past year, I have had the privilege and honor of being a part of the development team for this Center, and all I can say is that the people behind this are good salt of the earth people who practice mindfulness along with their research, and come from all walks of life.


The main goal of this event is connection. They are very much looking forward to meeting the community, and connecting to people who walk similar paths. So, whether you are a long time practitioner or just interested and want to take advantage of all the free workshops...this event is going to be very powerful for community building and really taking the next step. Click below for the facebook event page to show your support and for more info

https://www.facebook.com/events/171483423209825/

Pitt Mindfulness Fair Event Details:

Saturday March 19, 10am-3pm
Frick Fine Arts Building, Pittsburgh Pa, 15213

-Snacks Provided
-24 Free Worksh0ps
-Kids Activity Corner
-Great People :-)

24 workshops Topics will range from:

-Applications of Mindfulness in Education, Life and Relationships, Mindful Eating
-Practicing Meditation Techniques,Tai Chi Class, Yoga Class, etc..
-Therapeutic uses; Mindful Movement and more.
-Children’s Corner is planned with crafts, family yoga practices, and introduction to mindfulness for children.

We invite the entire community to connect, learn, and share If you like this event, then please share it with others....

We are a community here for each other..walking the same path.....its time to connect more:-)

Catch you soon

-Coach Tom
results.name: Awesome Event: Pitt Mindfulness Fair..Free Workshops, Food, Kids Stuff, etc.

results.description:
Wet Plate Collodion demonstration workshop with Jason Snyder of Pittsburgh Tintype Studio. Jason works with a process that was discovered in the late 1800's, using vintage equipment, he makes one of a kind photographs on metal and glass. Jason will explain the evolution, theory and technicalities of Wet Plate Collodion Photography, as well as his more personal visions about the use of photography as a means to communicate, develop and convey a specific message.
Exposure, development, stopping, fixing, rinsing, drying, and varnishing happens in one fell swoop. Each plate takes about 10-15 minutes to make to the rinsing stage. Typically we will make between 4-6 plates, and possibly a group plate that could be left with the group as a memory of the time spent.

Cost $30.00 for Members of NKAC / NKCC

Cost $40.00 for Non Members
results.name: Workshop - Wet Plate Collodion Demonstration

results.description:
Free Family-Friendly Brown Bag Concert

You're invited to a free Brown Bag concert as Pittsburgh Opera's Resident Artists serenade you in a special program highlighting one of the most popular styles of opera -- Bel Canto (which in Italian means "beautiful singing") that prevailed throughout most of Europe during the 18th century and early 19th centuries which was led by such famous Italian composers as Rossini, Bellini, and Donizetti.

March 19, 2016
  12:00 PM - 1:00 PM

Location: 2425 Liberty Avenue, in the Strip District

Free and open to the public, these monthly one-hour concerts feature Pittsburgh Opera Resident Artists in the George R. White Opera Studio at Pittsburgh Opera  Headquarters. Bring a friend and bring your lunch!  There is usually complimentary coffee, tea, and cookies.

The concert program will feature bel canto classics and perhaps a sneak peak of the upcoming Pittsburgh Opera production "The Barber of Seville" (which is one of the most famous bel canto operas by Gioachino Rossini) which will be performed during April 2-10, 2016 at the Benedum Center.

Doors open at 11:30 AM.  Please note that the Pittsburgh Opera  garage is available only for handicapped parking, by reservation. RESERVATIONS MUST BE RECEIVED BY 4:00 PM FRIDAY, March 18.

For more information about this Brown Bag Concert, please visit  http://pittsburghopera.org/calendar/detail/march-brown-bag-concert

For more information (including videos) about the upcoming Pittsburgh Opera production of "The Barber of Seville" (which is one of the most famous bel canto operas by Gioachino Antonio Rossini) which will be performed during April 2-10, 2016 at the Benedum Center, please visit http://pittsburghopera.org/show/the-barber-of-seville

For more information about Pittsburgh Opera and the complete line-up for the[masked] season, please visit http://pittsburghopera.org

For more information about bel canto operas, please visit https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bel_canto

So whether you're curious or just looking to take a little break while shopping in the Strip, please consider stopping by Pittsburgh Opera to enjoy their resident artists as they sing classics to give guests a little taste of opera.

And if you're relatively new to Meetup, this would be a nice event to attend to meet lots of people in a very relaxed, convenient setting.  Because the concert ends at 1 PM, your Saturday afternoon will still be open. Depending on the RSVPs and interests of the group, some people may decide to go out for an optional lunch or just walk around the Strip District checking out some places. 

Because we're expecting a large group, we'll also discuss various options for those that wish to continue their afternoon in the Strip District. For example, we may have 5-30+ Meetup members that might like to check out a few more things (say from 1:30- 5 PM) with the group.

Options for Spending Time in the Strip District After the Concert

In addition to many interesting restaurants, shops, bars, etc.,  there are some other great places within a short walk of the Pittsburgh Opera location:

1) Heinz History Center & Western Pennsylvania Sports Museum (1212 Smallman Street) http://www.heinzhistorycenter.org/ which features the new Toys of the ’50s, ’60s and ’70s Exhibit  (March 4, 2016 – May 31, 2016) http://www.heinzhistorycenter.org/exhibits/toys-50s-60s-70s Here is the visitor guide (to all 7 floors of incredible galleries) http://www.heinzhistorycenter.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/History-Center-Visitor-Guide-2015-April.pdf Admission is Adults ($16); Senior Citizens 62+ ($14); Retired & Active Duty Military ($6.50); Students with a valid school ID ($6.50); Children ages 6-17 ($6.50); Children ages 5 and under (Free)

2) Society for Contemporary Craft (2100 Smallman Street) http://contemporarycraft.org/ which contains the remarkable exhibit Mindful: Exploring Mental Health through Art (September 18, 2015 - March 26, 2016) http://contemporarycraft.org/exhibition/mindful/ To learn more about these artists and their inspiring personal stories, please visit http://www.exploremindfulart.com/ Check out these great articles from the City Paper and Trib about the exhibit http://www.pghcitypaper.com/pittsburgh/at-the-scc-a-wide-ranging-show-about-mental-health/Content?oid=1885259 and http://triblive.com/aande/museums/9096338-74/mental-says-thomas Admission is free although a suggested donation of $5 is also OK.
results.how_to_find_us: Meet in lobby at 11:30-11:45 AM before the noon performance. These concerts draw big crowds, so it is best to get there early. We will also gather in the lobby following the show for more coffee/tea, cookies, and discussions with the artists.
results.name: Free Brown Bag Concert at Pittsburgh Opera -- Bel Canto favorites

On Global Sisterhood Day, women from around the globe gather in small groups to celebrate the unique and important relationships between women, and engaged in meaningful conversation about their hearts, lives, and vision for the planet. Last year, over 2700 participants from more than 75 countries, participated in over 115 Sister Circles. This annual global event is an opportunity for us to collectively take a stand for a future that is only possible when we rise in connection, support and celebration of one another.


Join the Women’s Small Business Association, Inspiring Lives International, and the new non-profit the Global Sisterhood for bonding over a discussion at Grazie in the North Hills.  While attending is free, you are encouraged to order lunch if you would like as best selling author Dr. Shellie Hipsky leads us in discussion. Open to all women.

results.description:
We are having another Saturday gaming event at the Giant Market District Express with a fella that somehow lived through the Ides of March, Redbeard! 

So bring a game you want to try, or come try some games that you likely won't find in the toy aisle at Wal-Mart. These games come from all over the world. We have a group of folks who are usually excited to teach someone a new or a classic game, and we have people who are very game (sorry) to give any games that you may bring a shot. 

Experienced? Inexperienced? In between? Need a little coaching to get through your turn? Ready to give it a shot? Come out and see us! 

Drop in any time after Noon. People come and go all day. RSVPs are very appreciated, and allow me to know to not cancel the event, but drop in last minute if that's how life is working out for you. There is no admission to attend. If one person says they are certainly in, that's all I need to make the day worthwhile in my book. Hate to sit there with two bags of games like a dope.

There is a rather good selection on food as well. For those who would enjoy beers and especially craft beers, they do have such things on site. Also a Starbucks, but that's not my game. We'll be playing in the dining area. Note that the dining area and food preparation services both shut down at 10 PM. We try to wind things down at 9:30 to make life easier on the Giant Eagle Market District Express Staff.

If you have ideas for venues and towns in which to hold an event in mind, please do contact me. We know there are a lot of towns that hope to game that we are missing good events on the map. We have a lot of assistant organizers, and we're pretty liberal about handing out the duty and title, because all it truly means is you have taken the effort to arrange something, and you should be the contact for any questions about it. We don't need money or a great amount of time from you. Just a willing heart, a face welcoming to all comers, and your enthusiasm is all it really takes. We have games. Let's go make some gamers!

Text me with your questions here on meetup, in a Personal message, or on my cell (724)[masked] .

Come and listen! And also see some awesome DIY electronic music projects by our member Bob. Talkbox, Moog synthesizer, custom guitar amplifier, electric guitar.

Do you have music projects of your own? Come and share them. Do you want to learn to make your own guitar amp, synthesizer, musical tesla coil, theremin, and etc. Come and check out the Music and Technology Club.


Details about Music Club
Meets on the 3rd Saturday of every month and works on electronic musical instruments such as Theremins, Synthesizers,Musical Tesla Coils, Electric Guitars and Bass Guitars, vaccum tube amps for guitars.


In addition this club is also interested in learning about music theory, and potentially interested in forming a music band composed entirely of unusual musical instruments. We have a guy who made a guitar sound like a violin using an electric fan, a musical tesla coil, a soda can theremin, a DIY midi controlled pipe organ, and vacuum tube guitar amplifiers. You get the idea! This club is open to the public.

Join me on Saturday, March 19, 2016 to honor the Earth on our Spring Equinox! Moon will be waxing in Leo, a fun-loving time to celebrate the return of Spring.

We will walk a few trails through the woods of Boyce-Mayview and share our hopes and goals for the New Year and the seeds we intend to plant (figuratively AND literally!)  I would like to potentially hold a Circle Ceremony for this. We'll see how everyone's feeling!

Non-strenuous event.  Just bring your love and respect for the Earth <3
 And depending on the weather, maybe a hot beverage!

I will lead the group in a few choice Spring-related prayers/blessings, and open the floor for anyone/everyone else to do the same!  It will ideally be a community effort, where everyone feels honored and respected and open to share their Truth.

Sage and Mugwort burning will be at opening and closing of the ceremony. All feel free to bring yours along, too!  The more the merrier!

Check back for more details as we inch closer to this event, I may add more ideas/plans in the upcoming weeks.

I hope to see you there!
Green Blessings!

results.description:
The 2016 CMU IFF is thrilled to present a Q&A session with Chi-Raq director Spike Lee! The event will provide a unique opportunity to come “Face to Face” with a world-renowned filmmaker and to gain insights from Spike as he discusses his experiences in the world of filmmaking and beyond.

Co-Sponsored by Carnegie Mellon University’s Humanities Scholars Program, Sylvia and David Steiner Speaker Series, Center for the Arts in Society, Dietrich College Dean’s Office, AB Lectures, School of Art, Entertainment Technology Center, Department of English, Center for Africanamerican Urban Studies & the Economy (CAUSE).


BUY TICKETS HERE - get them now, tickets are selling fast!

Find FREE parking at the Forbes Avenue Parking Lot after 5pm!


ABOUT SPIKE LEE
Spike Lee is an award-winning, critically acclaimed film director who was most recently honored with the Academy Honorary Award. With a career full of outspoken, provocative films and documentaries such as Do the Right Thing, Malcolm X, Clockers, and 4 Little Girls, that challenge cultural assumptions regarding race, class, politics, and other social issues, who else could be more fitting to address “Faces of Conflict”?

Reception & Film Location

This event is General Admission (open seating) and takes place inside the Jared L. Cohen University Center (where the café areas are also located) next to the tennis courts.   And if you were standing on Forbes facing the main campus (near the bus shelter at Forbes & Morewood), you would see the famous 'Walking to the Sky' sculpture (where people appear to walking up a 10-story angled pole) in front of you, and the Cohen University Center would be very long building to your left. The McConomy Auditorium is on the 1st floor of the Cohen University Center. Please print out this campus map before you go http://www.cmu.edu/homeimages/campus-map/cmu_mapcolor_8x11.pdf -- the Cohen University Center is Building #13 on this map. 


Here is what the McConomy Auditorium looks like inside http://www.cmu.edu/cohon-university-center/reserve-space/event-spaces/mcconomy.html

CMU International Film Festival For the complete festival schedule and more info, including trailers of all of the films during CMU International Film Festival’s TENTH ANNIVERSARY season (March 17 - April 3, 2016), please visit http://www.cmu.edu/faces/index.html
results.name: “Face to Face” with Spike Lee (SOLD OUT)

Co-Sponsored by Carnegie Mellon University’s Humanities Scholars Program, Sylvia and David Steiner Speaker Series, Center for the Arts in Society, Dietrich College Dean’s Office, AB Lectures, School of Art, Entertainment Technology Center, Department of English, Center for Africanamerican Urban Studies & the Economy (CAUSE).

BUY TICKETS HERE - get them now, tickets are selling fast!

Find FREE parking at the Forbes Avenue Parking Lot after 5pm!


ABOUT SPIKE LEE
Spike Lee is an award-winning, critically acclaimed film director who was most recently honored with the Academy Honorary Award. With a career full of outspoken, provocative films and documentaries such as Do the Right Thing, Malcolm X, Clockers, and 4 Little Girls, that challenge cultural assumptions regarding race, class, politics, and other social issues, who else could be more fitting to address “Faces of Conflict”?
results.name: “Face to Face” with Spike Lee

PRESENTED by "ARTISTS' GALLERY"
FEATURING THE ARTWORK OF
ARNE HANSEN AND GORDON SATRI

Exhibit Receptions:
Friday and Saturday – March[masked]:30 PM – 8:30 PM

Get your creative juices flowing by celebrating the 2016 Artists’ Gallery’s “Art Gallery Weekend Event Series” of monthly exhibitions. Each monthly event in the 2016 series will feature works by many of our established and burgeoning visual artists, performances by professional musicians and student musicians from local colleges, we will feature a variety of published and unpublished poetry and novelistic readings by some of our local authors, plus beautiful performances by local performing artists. These events will be held on the last Friday and Saturday evenings of each month beginning in March. We hope you will take the time to explore the dozens of artists on display and enjoy a weekend high-lighted by a celebration of the arts in Bellevue. Friday, March 18 at 6:30 PM will launch this exciting new series with the artwork styles of Arne Hansen and Gordon Satri. Tristan Reid will read from a selection of his writings on Friday evening and Saturday, March 19, will feature poet Nick Romeo. We are pleased to present the jazz sounds of the “Dante Romito Band" on Friday and Saturday evening. The band will be performing their first instrumental rock single, the “Guardian Angel”.

results.description:
***We're meeting on a Saturday this time due to the availability of the majority of the group.***

There are secrets you share, and secrets you hide…

Growing up on her family’s Sonoma vineyard, Georgia Ford learned some important secrets. The secret number of grapes it takes to make a bottle of wine: eight hundred. The secret ingredient in her mother’s lasagna: chocolate. The secret behind ending a fight: hold hands.

But just a week before her wedding, thirty-year-old Georgia discovers her beloved fiancé has been keeping a secret so explosive, it will change their lives forever.

Georgia does what she’s always done: she returns to the family vineyard, expecting the comfort of her long-married parents, and her brothers, and everything familiar. But it turns out her fiancé is not the only one who’s been keeping secrets…

results.description:
Life is Meeting Ourselves

“All problems come from the inner to the outer.”

– Sri Harold Klemp, Wisdom of the Heart, Book 3, p. 97

The Eckankar Center of Western PA invites you to gather with others who have been touched by God’s love.


The ECK Worship Service lasts about one hour and is made up of three spiritual parts.  It begins with a short and uplifting reading from the works of Eckankar.  Following the reading, everyone is invited to sing HU, an ancient name for God.  The song of HU can open one’s heart to the love of God.  Anyone can benefit from this song of spiritual love regardless of age, background, or religion.  The HU song closes with a few moments of quiet contemplation and is followed by an open discussion of the morning’s topic.

For more information, visit:

results.description:
While the World Kaleidoscope at the Carnegie Library of Pittsburgh - Main has been rotated on every fourth Sunday of the month for many years, we are syncopating the rhythm of the series to present a very special third-Sunday-of-the-month performance by Sean Gaskell on March 20!

Gaskell will give a performance on the Kora, a 21-stringed harp from West Africa, featuring traditional songs that are the heart and soul of the Kora's musical repertoire, as well as some of his own personal compositions. 

The Kora is native to the Mande peoples who live within the countries of Gambia, Senegal, Mali, Guinea, and Guinea Bissau. The music is traditionally played by oral and musical historians known as "griots". The Kora is a melodic and seemingly peaceful instrument, which is somewhat contrary to its musical repertoire. Many songs tell ancient stories of war and hardship, while others praise people of high political status and those who helped expand the Mande empire. While the Kora is only 300 years old, some commonly played songs can be traced back 800 years to the founding of the Mande empires. Gaskell has studied extensively under the instruction of Malamini Jobarteh and Moriba Kuyateh of Brikama, the Gambia, and Kane Mathis of Brooklyn, NY. Gaskell has been featured at numerous festivals in the United States, Gambia, and Senegal.

Listen to these many strings pulling at your wanderlust here at the Library!

All ages.  Free.
results.name: FREE CONCERT: World Kaleidoscope presents Sean Gaskell

Don't miss your opportunity to hike in an urban setting. Join us for a tour of Pittsburgh, where we will stop along the way at Rita's Italian Ice for their annual "Start Spring off Right – with Free Italian Ice!" ACTIVITY LEVEL: Easy to Moderate. WHERE TO MEET: Allegheny T Station. WHAT TO BRING: Camera, weather-appropriate clothing (layers, no cotton), insulated waterproof footwear small day pack with extra clothes, snacks, water, personal medications. OPTIONAL RECOMMENDED ITEMS: Sunglasses.


Thank you for your interest in our free "Welcome Spring! Urban Hike Outing." L.L.Bean has a centralized reservation system. To guarantee your space, you must first confirm your reservation on our centralized reservation system, and if appropriate, fill out a participant agreement. Please visit www.llbean.com/pittsburgh, find this event on the "Event Calendar", and register. We look forward to seeing you!


Activity Level: 


Physical Ability/Cardiovascular Demand: Easy to Moderate
Level of Experience: Intro

Hike distance will be ~4 miles

What to bring:
Dress in Layers (avoid Cotton) 
Comfortable Outdoor Footwear
Water to stay hydrated 
Snacks 
Completed and signed L.L.Bean participant agreement Click Here


Optional: Camera, Optics, Lip Balm, Walking Stick or Trekking Poles, Personal Medicines

Minimum Age 8: This outing is open to ages 8 and above. Children 8 to 14 years of age need to be accompanied by a participating adult. Children 15 to 17 years old can participate alone after their parent has signed the L.L.Bean participant agreement for minors.


Need help preparing for your next adventure? Visit L.L.Bean Store at Ross Park Mall and ask to speak with an Outdoor Product Specialist. L.L.Bean will fit you with the right clothing and gear for all of life's adventures.

results.description:
CATS Dance hosts monthly contra dances at Carnegie Mellon University. Everyone is welcome, regardless of age, race, gender, or ability. We have a different band and caller each month - this month it's CMU's own Bob Frederking calling to the Panther Hollow String Band! See https://www.facebook.com/catsdancepgh/events for details!


No experience is necessary, but you can show up 15 minutes early if you'd like a mini-lesson from our veteran volunteers. 

Please help us pay for the band -- we suggest $10, but give whatever you're able to. We also welcome folks who'd like to help set up early (starting at 4:45pm) or pack up after the dance. Also - contra dancing is hungry business - if you like, please bring a snack to share at the break.

Here's a peek at a contra dance in action!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PGpkkb5wAtY

Please note that most of our community is not using Meetup.com. Though it may look like nobody is attending, rest assured that there will be lots of people at the dance! You can find us on Facebook at https://www.facebook.com/catsdancepgh/events!
results.how_to_find_us: Dances are held in the second floor "small gym" in old Skibo Gymnasium.

results.description:
The notion of a salutation to the sun is to pay your respects and surrender to the universe.  This is a metaphor to let go physically.  The mind follows the actions of the body; in short, it is a moving meditation.

Join Jen Stratakis, E-RYT for this beautiful practice; the tradition of 108 Sun Salutations is healing and energizing. The flow of poses will be accompanied by the traditional mantras for this classical series. Participants do NOT need to complete every sun salutation; but that challenge is there,  if you want it!

Pausing to rest is acceptable and encouraged. Simply stay in the spirit of the practice, with the option of resting in Mountain Pose or Child’s Pose.

We will end our practice with the release of a Chinese lantern to symbolize letting go of what you don't need, in this season of renewal.
results.name: Practice 108 Sun Salutes to Welcome Spring

results.description: Jesus was no fan of the Pharisees. Witness Matthew 23:13 - "Woe to you, teachers of the law and Pharisees, you hypocrites! You shut the door of the kingdom of heaven in people's faces. You yourselves do not enter, nor will you let those enter who are trying to." Whoa, indeed! So what is a Pharisee? Basically, it is someone who takes spiritual truth and makes it physical. The opposite of a Pharisee could be considered a Gnostic, someone who knows Truth by being Truth. In this group we will review the best of the best Gnostic literature and come closer to understanding what Jesus means when he quotes God Himself by saying, “Ye are gods.”

Music is usually selected from "The Daily Ukulele... 365 Songs for Better Living," by Liz and Jim Beloff. This book is readily available at music stores, book stores, and Amazon.com. Sometimes members bring other music to play (bring 15 copies to share). We usually play in a circle so bring a music stand if you have one  

Snacks and libations to share are welcome.

Note - watch for the large sign for the Church and then you will follow a narrow roadway back through the trees to the Church.

results.description:
Get Heard! Get Noticed! Get Leads! (TM)

Hosted by: Loraine Navoney of Freshtetic and Susan Green of Everskin

This is an informal networking event, open to any business woman who would like to increase her business contacts or clients in the Cranberry/Wexford area.

Things to bring:

- 10-20 business cards or marketing material

- cash for your lunch check

- $5 meeting fee (non members only)

AGENDA

1:00 pm - attendees arrive, reviews menu, gives the server their drink order, and open networking: everyone stands up to introduce oneself to others and pass their business card

1:15 pm - server takes lunch order and the sign in sheet is passed around

1:30 pm - 60 sec. commercials begin

2:00 pm - each person gives a testimony or referral for someone attending the lunch

2:30 pm - Premier member does a 5 min. company presentation

2:35 pm - WSBA announcements from Debi/Susan

2:45 pm - lunch has ended. Open networking is welcomed.

Be prepared to do a 60 second commercial and provide the following information.

- Your goal for attending or
- What is a good referral for you or
- Name one product or service they offer that will specifically help small business owners or business professionals.

Please RSVP if you plan to attend this lunch. If your schedule becomes free the day of the lunch, then you may attend without an RSVP. This lunch is subject to cancellation when the lunch has 3 or less RSVPs. Lunch cancellation policy.

If you are not a WSBA member and would like to attend as a guest, please contact <a>Kimfitnesschic</a> at [masked] 

If you have an interest in becoming a General member ($50/year) or Premier member ($100/year) of WSBA, please contact <a>Debi Arnett</a> at [masked]

Any non member is subject to removal from this if they RSVP for an event and they do not attend.

results.description:
Join us on Tuesdays for American Mah Jong! Folks begin arriving around 5PM, and play begins table by table as soon as we have three or four players plus a set.  (We usually have 3-5 tables.)  By 6:15 or so, most players have arrived. We rotate among the tables... at the end of each game, East walks around to see if another table is close to the end of their game, so that two players can swap places.   At the other end of the evening... play must end by 9PM when Panera closes.  Tables begin wrapping up play any time after 8:15 or so.


If you have never played, or if you have not played for a very long time, we highly recommend that you take a Mah Jong 101 beginner class before playing with us - beginner classes are offered every few months.  Mah jong is a wonderful game, but it's hard to learn by just watching others play!


Please order your 2015 card from the National Mah Jongg League, here: http://www.nationalmahjonggleague.org/ Amazon.com also carries the cards. Note that you want the NMJL card, and no other! (There are some colorful alternatives out there.. but we play NMJL card and rules.)

Experienced players -- please bring your cards and please bring a set if you have one.

Please do not bring any outside food or beverages into Panera! Instead, please plan to buy *something* from Panera, even if it's just a beverage or a cookie, to support their willingness to host us.
results.how_to_find_us: Hard to miss us, look for the Mah Jong sets!

With her signature charm, wit and humor, Jennifer introduces new patterns and explains their construction and application. You will go away with some new ideas to practice and a smile on your face.

Beginners are warmly welcomed.  Bring your own supplies, or use ones that Jennifer generously provides.  There is a "donations can" for anyone wishing to help support the ongoing costs for this meet-up and for supplies.

BONUS EXTRA:  Come early, 5-5:45 p.m., for social time, chat and generally hanging out together with fellow tanglers.

Let's venture out the parkway west, to the newly opened Walnut Grill! Once there, we can enjoy a 5pm Happy Hour and a 6pm sit down dinner. 

Please make sure that you RSVP if you would like to join us for dinner (Please do NOT rsvp if ONLY attending the Happy Hour. Just leaving a comment would be fantastic! ).  

At this moment, we only have reservations available for 15 people.  But I will request more seats if our RSVPs fill up.  And of course, if you RSVP, but then find out that you cannot attend, please delete your RSVP, as space may be limited for dinner.  We look forward to seeing you!

It is PPSC's strict policy that any unannounced no-shows to a dinner will result in that member being BLOCKED from the group.  Also, to help me avoid the evil glares from restaurant managers when our dinner attendance numbers drop by half, if a member backs out (but gives advance notice) TWICE during their membership, they will also be BLOCKED from the group.  This is a very strict policy, and we strongly recommend that you do NOT reserve for a dinner until you are sure that you can attend.  This is very important, because I am being told that people are being discouraged from attending due to the events being "fully booked."  Thanks!!!


A donation of a dollar per person would be appreciated, but not required, as the website is not free (please do not donate electronically...).  Yes, we accept quarters lollll....

Until then...!

[This is a passthrough - RSVP here: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/1losVbZIijwbyMnitGqndeLG--0Ss-s73xwSklz7IzZw/viewform ]

Matt Bauman, a Pitt graduate student, created a way to use cell phone video and open source software to track the speeds of cars. ( http://bikepgh.org/2015/11/13/guerrilla-style-pitt-student-uses-cell-phone-to-track-traffic-speeds-on-forbes-ave-in-oakland/)

Like many of us, Matt was frustrated with the persistently terrible conditions for bicyclists on the Fifth/Forbes corridor in Oakland.

To follow up, Traffic21 in partnership with BikePGH will host a Hacknight on March 22nd. Open Pittsburgh members are encouraged to attend.

The event will explore further opportunities for Bauman’s work and how to develop it into a tool for advocacy that can inform decision-makers. After presentations the attendees will split into two groups – 1. Those who want their fingers on the keyboards to discuss coding and 2. Those who are less technical and want to talk about user interface. CMU faculty researchers will also attend.
results.name: DIY Speed Monitoring: A Hacknight with Matt Bauman

results.description:
$69/player special.  Full teams and individuals have already signed up via our website. So don't be shy! 

Men’s & Coed League @ Cool Springs Sports Center...Brand NEW Facility in Bethel Park 

This is a BRAND NEW facility located about 20 minutes south of downtown. Two beautiful hard wood courts will be in play. Great locker rooms and amenities. This is an AMAZING value as we launch our new leagues and welcome new players. Note that this is a 6 week program to start. Spring will start in early March and returning fall teams will have priority placement.

Sign up as an individual - great way to meet new friends! - with a group of friends - or as a full team.  

Choose from:

Tuesday Men's - intermediate Level (starts March 22nd)

Wednesday Men's - Rec  (starts March 23rd)

What's included in the  price? 

• 7 weeks of regular season plus up to two weeks of playoffs

• 2 paid referees + scorekeeper

• Two 20 minutes halves


• Championship prize for winning team: Choice of customized apparel or trophy!

• Food/Drink specials at sponsor bar

Format  
Full Court

When are we playing?  
This league plays a round robin regular season with game times rotating from 7:00 PM through 11:00 PM. A full season schedule and standings will be available on sportsmonster.net by week 2. 

Playing surface and what to wear:  
We play on a hardwood court. Athletic shoes are required. Teams must wear same-colored, permanent numbered shirts.

Level of competition:

- Recreational level is ideal for teams just forming, teams with a mix of experienced and novice players and maybe teams that have lost a step or two over the years and are looking for a more relaxed environment. 

- Intermediate level is for teams and players looking for a faster and more skilled atmosphere. Everyone playing has either played high school, club ball or IM's in college, knows the game and is solid in all fundamentals and sharp in certain skills. 


These leagues are happening! Don't see a bunch of people registered here? Don't worry! Many people and teams register directly on our sportsmonster.net website instead. So go ahead and sign up to play! 

Full Team Registration
*Want to Register as a Full Team? -- If you want to register a full team, you can do so but roster size MUST be at least 10. And yes, you can pay for all of them here. If players are signing up on their own, have each player/group be sure to reference one another so we know to place you together -- see questions when you RSVP. 

When will I find out which team I'm on? 
Once a team is formed, a roster will be provided to all the players and we ask someone from the team to volunteer to act as captain to ensure a full team is showing up each week and a positive vibe is maintained throughout the season. 

Don't have PayPal? You may register through Sportsmonster.net and pay by check or money order but you will be paying full value as presented on that site. 

If you have any questions please don't hesitate to ask.  
Call: [masked] 
E-mail: ryan @ sportsmonster.net

All registrations made through this Meetup event agree to the terms and conditions found on sportsmonster.net.

results.description:
2nd to last Climb that I'm posting till November.

Hiking & biking season starts!

Tues. Mar 22nd Climb the Cathedral then Lulu's!

Tues. Mar 29th Climb the Cathedral then Hemingway's! 21+ Event

Climb the Cathedral of Learning Stairs for an Hour, then Lulu's Noodles!

Meet at 6:50pm by the benches by the 1st Floor Cathedral of Learning Elevators. We climb the Back Stairwell (Stairwell A) starting exactly at 7pm, then climb as many floors as we can in a hour taking the elevator DOWN to rest and do it again. Couch Potatoes can usually do it 1-2 times people that are in shape can do it 3-5 times, super shape 4-7 times. Then we walk to Lulu's Noodles on South Craig Street and catch a bite because we earned it!

GREAT FOOD: Lulu's Noodles address: 300 South Craig Street  (great soups, bubble teas and mixed asian fare).

Parking is on street, FREE after 6pm on S. Bellefield, S. Craig and S. Dithridge Streets.

Wear light clothing and put coats on 36th floor and keep your valuables on you. Water Bottle or Camelback recommended.  It gets HOT in the Stairwells!

My phone for TEXT contact is[masked] remember I will be driving in from 40 mins away so will respond after my car is parked!

results.description:
The ACM Pittsburgh is back for another exciting year! Please join us for our first meetup of 2016, as we have Ted Dunning, Chief Application Architect at MapR talking about the latest innovations in Machine Learning.

Abstract:

Big data is beginning to make a big difference when it comes to building machine learning systems. Moreover, many of the methods for building these systems don’t require years of study before you can apply them. In this talk, Ted will present examples of key principles that really matter in making choices about data, algorithms and architecture when you build practical learning systems, as well as other key learning that come from his experience. 

Agenda:

7:00pm: Refreshments

7:15pm: Announcements

7:25pm - Tech Talk

8:10pm - Q&A

8:25pm - Conversations

8:55pm - Departure

Speaker's Bio:

Ted Dunning is Chief Application Architect at MapR Technologies and committer and PMC member of the Apache Mahout, Apache ZooKeeper, and Apache Drill projects . Ted has been very active in mentoring new Apache projects and is currently serving as vice president of incubation for the Apache Software Foundation .  Ted was the chief architect behind the MusicMatch (now Yahoo Music) and Veoh recommendation systems. He built fraud detection systems for ID Analytics (LifeLock) and he has 24 patents issued to date and a dozen pending. Ted has a PhD in computing science from the University of Sheffield. When he’s not doing data science, he plays guitar and mandolin. He also bought the beer at the first Hadoop user group meeting.

Food Sponsor:

About MapR Technologies

MapR delivers on the promise of Hadoop with a proven, enterprise-grade platform that supports a broad set of mission-critical and real-time production uses. MapR brings unprecedented dependability, ease-of-use and world-record speed to Hadoop, NoSQL, database and streaming applications in one unified distribution for Hadoop. MapR is used by more than 700 customers across financial services, government, healthcare, internet, manufacturing, media, retail and telecommunications as well as by leading Global 2000 and Web 2.0 companies. Amazon, Cisco, Google, Teradata and HP are part of the broad MapR partner ecosystem. Investors include Google Capital, Lightspeed Venture Partners, Mayfield Fund, NEA, Qualcomm Ventures and Redpoint Ventures. MapR is based in San Jose, CA. Connect with MapR on Facebook, LinkedIn, and Twitter.

Read more about MapR through their Fast Facts

Getting there:

This map details where to go for parking and the talk:

There are 3 parking lots shown in blue. The far left lot is open air, and the other two are parking garages. The two closest lots to the talk are paid parking. The further lot should be free after 5pm. Follow the black arrows to enter the parking lots. Although there is construction shown in red, you can walk around the fence if you stay on the sidewalk.


The talk is located in Newell Simon Hall, room 1305. If you enter where the green arrow is shown, you will walk into the building a little ways and see the elevators on your right. Take them down to floor 1. Room 1305 will be directly to your left when you exit the elevator.

The address of the university is 5000 Forbes Avenue if you need driving directions to the general area. Other maps of CMU's campus can be found here: http://www.cmu.edu/visit/
results.name: “Practical Machine Learning: How To Decide What Really Matters" with Ted Dunning

results.description:
Join us for a 2-hour session of indoor volleyball open gym! You'll get a ton of playing time in a well-organized event. Our host will check players in, divide players into teams, and make sure that everything runs smoothly. All you have to do is show up ready to play!

Pricing:

• $7 - RSVP online and pay in advance (online rsvp closes at 4:30 pm!)

• $9 - RSVP and pay cash at the event

• $10 - Show up and play - be sure to check online to make sure there is room!

What to Wear: We are playing indoors on a rubberized all-sport surface. Most players wear volleyball-specific shoes, but gym shoes are also allowed. Please bring your shoes and change into them at the facility. This will help keep the floor clean of dirt and water.

What to Expect: Show up early! The games will begin at the time posted for this event. Players can start checking in with the event host as early as 15 minutes before the scheduled start time. If a court is available, you may begin warming up before the event begins. We limit play to 42 players per evening, which is 3 teams of 7 players per court. If we have 3 teams on a court, winners stay once and then shuffle out so everyone gets to play. If less people are in attendance, we divide based on who is there and mix things up half way through the session.

Level of Play: This event is open to all levels of play. We do our best to create even teams so that games are well-matched. Our ideal scenario is having one court of higher skilled players and one court of more recreational players. There are no referees, so players need to play with sportsmanship and make their own calls. We aim to make everyone feel welcome at these events.

Facility Information: Monroeville Sports Center is located at 855 Macbeth Drive in Monroeville. Parking should be ample in the free lot.

Minimum number of players and playing formats. This event needs a minimum of 12 people (not including the host) signed up before the start of the event in order to run. An email notification will be sent if we cancel. Refunds or credits will be issued if we cancel the event. Sign up early to encourage more people to sign up!!

Do Your Part! Help us keep an accurate guest count! If you RSVP, we're counting on you to be there. If you change your mind about playing or your guest count changes, please update your RSVP. No-Shows will be marked on your account. If space is tight, we hold RSVP spots 10 minutes into advertised start and then open spots to walk-ups.

Requirements to play: This is an adult volleyball group. You must be 19 older. Males and females of all skill levels are welcome to play. There is no required gender ratio. Players are expected to conduct themselves with good sportsmanship.

What's included in the price? Your payment helps to cover the rental costs, the hourly pay for your event host, and ensures a well-organized event.

Questions? Post your question in the comments section of this meetup and the event host or one of our organizers will reply. You can also message the organizers directly through meetup. Or, give us a call M-F 8:00am-12:30pm:[masked]-7130.

results.description:
Welcome to Winter Aristacrats!

It's a New Year and with it a new set of interesting technology topics at the Arista Iron City Meetup Group. 

For the March 23rd Meetup, we provide a live demo of VMTurbo use cases:

"East-West" Latency: effectively manage between localizing frquently communicating workloads vs. access to compute and storage resources

Buffer Congestion: incorporate LANZ into decision engine to shape traffic and avoid packet loss

Hybrid Cloud Deployment: intelligence of which workloads to burst and when

VMTurbo’s Application Performance Control platform enables organizations to manage cloud and enterprise virtualization environments to maximize infrastructure investments while assuring application performance. VMturbo’s Network Control Module and its support for Arista EOS extends Operations Manager into the network layer leveraging the efficient market principles to manage the tradeoffs between compute and storage loads vs. localizing network traffic flow.

For a preview, check out these links to Arista & VMTurbo Integration:

Arista VMTurbo Network Control Module - End Users

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wDyCmEbBYPo&feature=youtu.be Arista 

Network Control Module - Assure Performance through Network Aware Decisions

http://cdn.vmturbo.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/06/VMT-Arista-Network-Control-Module-Data-Sheet-June-2015.pdf

Meetup Location: 

For March, we're at the Pittsburgh Technology Council, 2000, Technology Dr, Pittsburgh, PA 15219. When you enter the PTC office, take a left and go all the way down the hall to the conference room. 

If you wish to send your full name to us privately so we can add you or guests on the list, join our meetup group and message us privately. 


If you wish to send your full name to us privately so we can add you or guests on the list, join our meetup group and message us privately.

(fresh local beer, drinks and pizza will be served)

Look for more updates or changes as the date approaches, and see you there.

Tony Williams 

(twilliams @ arista.com)[masked]

Joe Yohannan

(joeyo @ arista.com)[masked]

Ben Yemini - Sr. Director of Product MarketingVMTurbo

Phone:[masked]

Email: [masked]
